reviews.review:
(original edit, 60 hours played) Incredible

edit: i have poured 200 hours into this game and i don't plan on stopping
edit 2: 237 hours in and 88 achievements have been acquired, i am going to get them all

edit 3: around ~650 hours and i'm still learning maybe ~70% of the killers (all their little tricks) and still trying to master all of them; there's literally so much to learn in this game which either sounds lovely or awful depending on how you feel about those kinds of things
wonderful game
more fun with friends but still enjoyable solo, ghostface is mighty fine too
queue times make me wanna cry

*No permito comentarios porque es una comunidad extremadamente toxica e inmadura la de DBD y mayormente destacan en escribir Puras incoherencias y toxiqueadas. Lo mas normal es que cayese el TÃ­pico Grupito de amiguitos/as que juegan 24HS de Sobreviviente en PreMade a defender el Dead By Daylight que es su vida prÃ¡cticamente (Cuando ni los agredÃ­s, solo DecÃ­s la realidad de el pesimo funcionamiento del juego en todo sentido, pero bueno...)

The epitome of a Love/Hate relationship.

Like any game it's going to have its ups and down, which is more so due to the players in the community rather than the game itself. Even with the rage quitting, the occasional killer who insists on removing all fun from the world and the pure lack of situational awareness by random teammates, I recommend the game.

You'll waste more time than you care to admit as you run around each semi-randomly generated map hunting the survivors, or searching for generators. You'll laugh, you'll cry and you'll certainly scream (looking at you silent killers). This is amplified if you are playing with friends and end up with a random person or two on your survivor team. Having an outside source of voice communication is key to survival.

DLC is both affordable and consistently released to keep the game from feeling stale. New killers and survivors aren't pushed down your throat as a "pay to win" advantage, because at a certain point in your progression they're purely graphical. If one of the new releases has a skill you want, you can certainly purchase it to obtain the unlocked skill faster for the main character of your choice. Or, if you're patient, you can obtain skills from killers and survivors you don't own through their weekly in game shrine.

Also one of the few games I regularly buy the season pass for, leveling is quick and the cosmetics you unlock are more than worth it for the cost.
Speaking of cosmetics, those are another fun feature of any game. Who doesn't want to look amazing while running through the woods, screaming and trying not to be murdered? You can be impatient and buy cosmetics with actual funds, naturally, or you can earn shards while you play normally and unlock nearly everything utilizing them instead.

Overall the game is a great time in small doses. That fuse gets considerably shorter for each random player in your group. Don't forget, you can also filter out cross play if you're the type that hates dealing with the mixed bag of players. By default, you'll be matched with everyone!
Only play if you hate yourself.

Despite all its bugs and glitches..and poor coding and what not.. the game can be fun! However, I suggest custom matches with friends. Also, the community may be somewhat toxic but there are some goodies out there!
Takes way to long to update and verify bro!
Si te gustaba la popa y esquivar a todos para que no te toquen, este juego te va a gustar.
